title: Module-5-Assignment
contents:
# Name: Skylar Walsh
# Professor: Lingyao Li
# Course: LIS4273.002
# Date: 2/11/2025

# "Question A"

# The director of manufacturing at a cookies company needs to determine 
# whether a new machine is able to produce a particular type of cookies 
# according to the manufacturer's specifications, which indicate that 
# cookies should have a mean of 70 and standard deviation of 3.5 pounds. 
# A sample of 49 cookies reveals a sample mean breaking strength of 69.1 pounds.

# A1. State the null and alternative hypothesis

# "The null hypothesis (H0) would be that the breaking strength of the cookies
# is equal to 70 pounds."

# "The alternative hypothesis (Ha) would be that the breaking strength of
# the cookies is not equal to 70 pounds."

# A2. Is there evidence that the machine is not meeting the manufacturer's 
# specifications for average strength? Use a 0.05 level of significance

# Here are the sample statistics we are dealing with
sSize <- 49
sMean <- 69.1
pStdDev <- 3.5

# Here is the level of significance that will be used
a <- 0.05

# Here is the population mean
mu <- 70

# Calculate the z-score
z <- (sMean - mu) / (pStdDev/sqrt(sSize))
z

[1] -1.8

# A3. Compute the p value and interpret its meaning


# Calculate the p-value. This is a two-tailed test
pVal <- 2 * pnorm(abs(z), lower.tail = FALSE)
pVal

[1] 0.07186064

# Make the interpretation
if (pVal < a) {
  cat("Reject H0. There is enough evidence to suggest that the machine 
      is not meeting the manufacturer's specifications
      for the average strength")
} else {
  cat("Fail to reject H0. There is not enough evidence to suggest that
       the machine is not meeting the manufacturer's specifications 
       for the average strength")
}

Fail to reject H0. There is not enough evidence to suggest that
       the machine is not meeting the manufacturer's specifications 
       for the average strength

# A4. What would be your answer in (B) if the standard deviation were 
# specified as 1.75 pounds?

# The population standard deviation is now 1.75
pStdDev <- 1.75

# Calculate the z-score
z <- (sMean - mu) / (pStdDev/sqrt(sSize))
z

[1] -3.6

# Calculate the p-value. This is a two-tailed test
pVal <- 2 * pnorm(abs(z), lower.tail = FALSE)
pVal

[1] 0.0003182172

# Make the interpretation
if (pVal < a) {
  cat("Reject H0. There is enough evidence to suggest that the machine 
      is not meeting the manufacturer's specifications
      for the average strength")
} else {
  cat("Fail to reject H0. There is not enough evidence to suggest that
       the machine is not meeting the manufacturer's specifications 
       for the average strength")
}

Reject H0. There is enough evidence to suggest that the machine 
      is not meeting the manufacturer's specifications
      for the average strength

# A5. What would be your answer in (B) if the sample mean were 69 pounds 
# and the standard deviation is 3.5 pounds?

# The sample mean is now 69
sMean <- 69

# The population standard deviation is now 3.5
pStdDev <- 3.5

# Calculate the z-score
z <- (sMean - mu) / (pStdDev/sqrt(sSize))
z

[1] -2

# Calculate the p-value. This is a two-tailed test
pVal <- 2 * pnorm(abs(z), lower.tail = FALSE)
pVal

[1] 0.04550026

# Make the interpretation
if (pVal < a) {
  cat("Reject H0. There is enough evidence to suggest that the machine 
      is not meeting the manufacturer's specifications
      for the average strength")
} else {
  cat("Fail to reject H0. There is not enough evidence to suggest that
       the machine is not meeting the manufacturer's specifications 
       for the average strength")
}

Reject H0. There is enough evidence to suggest that the machine 
      is not meeting the manufacturer's specifications
      for the average strength

# "Question B"

# If xbar = 85, population standard deviation = 8, and n = 64, set up
# 95% confidence interval estimate of the population mean mu.

# List the set of values given
sMean <- 85
pStdDev <- 8
sSize <- 64
conLevel <- 0.95

# Calculate the z-score for the given confidence level
a <- 1 - conLevel
a

[1] 0.05

# This is a two-tailed test, so alpha will be cut in half
z_crit <- qnorm(1 - a/2)
z_crit

[1] 1.959964

# Solve for e, which stands for the margin of error
e <- z_crit * (pStdDev / sqrt(sSize))
e

[1] 1.959964

# Calculate the upper and lower limit to set up the
# 95% confidence interval

lower_limit <- sMean - e
lower_limit

[1] 83.04004

upper_limit <- sMean + e
upper_limit

[1] 86.95996

# Confidence interval
print("(83.04, 86.96)")

[1] "(83.04, 86.96)"

# There is a 95% probability that the population mean would be
# in between these two values


# "Question C"
library(GGally)
# Given the time spent on assignments each week for the sampled 
# girl group and boy group, respectively,

girls_grades <- c(89, 90, 91, 95, 98, 99, 96, 99)
girls_time_spend <- c(19, 20, 22, 25, 28, 30, 32, 36)

boys_grades <- c(86, 84, 92, 93, 93, 96, 98, 98)
boys_time_spend <- c(15, 19, 22, 23, 25, 29, 30, 40)

# Please perform the correlation analysis:

# C1. Calculate the correlation coefficient (Pearson) between time 
# spent and grade for girls' and boys' data sets, respectively.

corrData <- data.frame("Girls Grades"=girls_grades,
                       "Girls Time"=girls_time_spend, "Boys Grades"=boys_grades,
                       "Boys Time"=boys_time_spend)

# Here is the Pearson correlation

cor(corrData, method = "pearson")

             Girls.Grades Girls.Time Boys.Grades Boys.Time
Girls.Grades    1.0000000  0.9066710   0.8497687 0.8336184
Girls.Time      0.9066710  1.0000000   0.9162145 0.9661979
Boys.Grades     0.8497687  0.9162145   1.0000000 0.8621872
Boys.Time       0.8336184  0.9661979   0.8621872 1.0000000

# Here is the Spearman correlation

cor(corrData, method = "spearman")

             Girls.Grades Girls.Time Boys.Grades Boys.Time
Girls.Grades    1.0000000  0.9101960   0.8424397 0.9101960
Girls.Time      0.9101960  1.0000000   0.9639254 1.0000000
Boys.Grades     0.8424397  0.9639254   1.0000000 0.9639254
Boys.Time       0.9101960  1.0000000   0.9639254 1.0000000

# Here is the plot to compare the time spent
# and grade for both girls and boys data sets
ggpairs(corrData, upper = list(wrap("cor", size = 5)),
diag = list(continuous = "densityDiag"),)

title: Module-4-Assignment
contents:
# Name: Skylar Walsh
# Professor: Lingyao Li
# Course: LIS4273.002
# Date: 2/8/2025

# "Question A"
# Based on Table 1, what is the probability of

# A1. Event A
A <- 30/90
A

[1] 0.3333333

# A2. Event B
B <- 30/90
B

[1] 0.3333333

# A3. Event A or B
AUB <- A + B - (10/90)
AUB

[1] 0.5555556

# A4. P(A or B) = P(A) + P(B)
AUB == A + B

[1] FALSE

# "Question B"
# B1. Is this answer True or False.
print("TRUE")

[1] "TRUE"

# Please explain why
cat("The answer is True because we determined that
    there is a low initial probability of an event occurring (A1) before
    the weather man made the report (B). This explains why even a seemingly 
    accurate prediction can be misleading if the probability of an event 
    is very low. If it only normally rains 5 out of 365
    days, there is a historically low probability for rain. Even after
    learning the new information, it does not significantly
    change the prior belief enough for it to become very likely.
    If rain were to occur on more days, then the weather mans
    prediction would be more likely to happen. Bayes' Theorem
    still indicates a good chance of not raining.")

The answer is True because we determined that
    there is a low initial probability of an event occurring (A1) before
    the weather man made the report (B). This explains why even a seemingly 
    accurate prediction can be misleading if the probability of an event 
    is very low. If it only normally rains 5 out of 365
    days, there is a historically low probability for rain. Even after
    learning the new information, it does not significantly
    change the prior belief enough for it to become very likely.
    If rain were to occur on more days, then the weather mans
    prediction would be more likely to happen. Bayes' Theorem
    still indicates a good chance of not raining.

# "Question C"
# For a disease known to have a postoperative complication frequency of 20%, 
# a surgeon suggests a new procedure.She/he tests it on 10 patients and found 
# there are not complications. 

# C1. What is the probability of operating on 10 patients successfully with the
# traditional method?

# List the required parameters
numPatients <- 10
successPer <- 0.8
numSuccess <- 10

# Solve problem with the dbinom function
probOfSuccess <- dbinom(numSuccess, size = numPatients, prob = successPer)
# Print the probability
probOfSuccess

[1] 0.1073742

title: Module-3-Assignment
contents:
# Name: Skylar Walsh
# Professor: Lingyao Li
# Course: LIS4273.002
# Date: 2/1/2025



# Define two sets of data
firstSet <- c(10, 2, 3, 2, 4, 2, 5)
firstSet

[1] 10  2  3  2  4  2  5

secondSet <- c(20, 12, 13, 12, 14, 12, 15)
secondSet

[1] 20 12 13 12 14 12 15

# A1.
# "Central Tendency"
# Solve the mean, median, and mode of both data sets
# First set mean:
mean(firstSet)

[1] 4

# First set median:
median(firstSet)

[1] 3

# First set mode:
Mode(firstSet)

[1] 2
attr(,"freq")
[1] 3

# Second set mean:
mean(secondSet)

[1] 14

# Second set median:
median(secondSet)

[1] 13

# Second set mode:
Mode(secondSet)

[1] 12
attr(,"freq")
[1] 3

# A2.
# "Variation"
# Compute the range, interquartile, variance,
# and standard deviation for both sets.
# First set min and max:
firstSetMinMax <- range(firstSet)
firstSetMinMax

[1]  2 10

# First set range:
firstSetRange <- max(firstSet) - min(firstSet)
firstSetRange

[1] 8

# First set quartiles:
quantile(firstSet)

  0%  25%  50%  75% 100% 
 2.0  2.0  3.0  4.5 10.0 

# First set interquartile range:
IQR(firstSet)

[1] 2.5

# First set variance:
var(firstSet)

[1] 8.333333

# First set standard deviation:
sd(firstSet)

[1] 2.886751

# Second set min and max:
secondSetMinMax <- range(secondSet)
secondSetMinMax

[1] 12 20

# Second set range:
secondSetRange <- max(secondSet) - min(secondSet)
secondSetRange

[1] 8

# Second set quartiles:
quantile(secondSet)

  0%  25%  50%  75% 100% 
12.0 12.0 13.0 14.5 20.0 

# Second set interquartile range:
IQR(secondSet)

[1] 2.5

# Second set variance:
var(secondSet)

[1] 8.333333

# Second set standard deviation:
sd(secondSet)

[1] 2.886751

# A3.
# "Comparison"
# Compare results between the first and second set by
# discussing the differences between the two sets.
summary(firstSet)

   Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max. 
    2.0     2.0     3.0     4.0     4.5    10.0 

summary(secondSet)

   Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max. 
   12.0    12.0    13.0    14.0    14.5    20.0 

# Although both sets have the same range, standard deviation,
# variance, and interquartile range, they have a different
# mean, which will affect the coefficient of variance.
# Coefficient of variation as percent:
# First set:
sd(firstSet)/mean(firstSet)*100

[1] 72.16878

# Second set:
sd(secondSet)/mean(secondSet)*100

[1] 20.61965

# Because the first set has a larger coefficient of variation...
# the data is spread away from the mean on a larger interval.

title: Module 2 Assignment
description: The myMean function calculates the mean.
contents:
# Name: Skylar Walsh
# Professor: Lingyao Li
# Course: LIS4273.002
# Date: 1/24/2025

# The variable assignment2 has a vector with a total of 9 elements
assignment2 <- c(6, 18, 14, 22, 27, 17, 22, 20, 22)

# Define a function called myMean that will calculate the average
# of a vector. In the body of the function, we are adding all of
# the elements from the assignment2 variable and then dividing by how many
# items are in assignment2
myMean <- function(assignment2) {return(sum(assignment2)/length(assignment2))}

# Run the function, print the mean result into the console.
myMean(assignment2)

[1] 18.66667

title: My LIS4273 Blog
description: This is for LIS4273 advanced stats.
